What are Verus Smart Transactions, and how do they compare to Komodo compatible crypto-conditions? Additionally, what is VerusHash, and how has it evolved to promote a balanced mining environment?

Verus Smart Transactions are a new technology introduced in the Verus network, which replaces the use of Komodo compatible crypto-conditions. This technology allows for the creation of smart transactions on the Verus network, enabling advanced functionality and use cases. One of the key benefits of Verus Smart Transactions is that they use standard Bitcoin-style serialization, which makes it simpler to implement support on lite or mobile wallets compared to the crypto-condition protocol.

In contrast, Komodo compatible crypto-conditions are a different technology that was previously used on the Verus network. While they provided some advanced functionality, they were more complex and difficult to implement, especially on mobile or lite wallets.

VerusHash, on the other hand, is a hashing algorithm developed by the Verus team to promote a balanced mining environment. The goal of VerusHash is to equalize the performance of Field-Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) and Central Processing Units (CPUs) on the network. This is achieved by designing the algorithm to be resistant to the dominance of FPGAs, which have traditionally held a significant performance advantage over CPUs.

VerusHash 2.0 was the first version of the algorithm, which successfully equalized the performance of FPGAs and CPUs. The latest version, VerusHash 2.1, introduces an adjustment to the equalization technology, which is expected to tilt the balance even more favorably towards CPUs while still allowing FPGAs to operate on the hash algorithm with minor modifications.

The Verus team has proactively reached out to FPGA manufacturers and made the new algorithm available to them, ensuring that everyone has an opportunity to mine and stake on the network. This approach promotes a more decentralized and balanced mining environment, where individuals with different types of hardware can participate and contribute to the network's security.

## VerusHash 2.1
VerusHash 2.0 was the first algorithm to significantly equalize FPGAs dominance over CPUs, once they were introduced on the Verus network. While FPGAs were intentionally not blocked completely, which would simply drive the performance battle to the higher end and further into secret, the VerusHash 2.0 algorithm was developed to explicitly equalize FPGAs and modern CPUs and has met its original goals in keeping FPGA performance for the price under 2x of CPU. VerusHash 2.1 introduces an adjustment to the equalization technology, which we expect to tilt the balance a bit more favorably towards CPUs, while still enabling FPGAs to operate on the hash algorithm with minor modifications.
